There aren't ONLY (insulin secreting) beta cells in your pancreas, there are 5 cell types that secrete a whole bunch of hormones -glucagon, insulin, somatostatin, ghrelin, and pancreatic polypeptide. For us, our pancreas is destroyed, but by only taking insulin, we are only replacing that one hormone and not the other hormones that have also been taken out as a result of the autoimmune process. 

My endo also had me not go up to the highest dose, which would have been my next step. I am currently at 2.4 mg daily. It is still working well.

The reason you need to change your site every 2-3 days is because scar tissue starts to become a major issue if you regularly don’t rotate sites. Nobody is forcing you to change sites more often, but eventually you will see random absorption issues where your insulin isn’t working as fast as it should.

How do you tell the difference between why the insulin isn’t working?
So I have only been diagnosed with type 1 diabetes for just over a year now. I’m on humulog on the tandem tslim and dexcom.  It’s hard to describe my question but how do you know it your insulin isn’t working due to a bad site or the insulin is dead? Or you just are being a little resistance at the moment? And or if the meal I have just sucked and my timing of blousing was just crappy?

comments.text:
Im skeptical of "acute insulin resistance". The insulin is doing something, it's fighting a protein spike, fighting delayed carbs because of fat, fighting dehydration, or fighting blood sugar from stress.

Enough insulin will bring it down. Check the site, if insulin isn't leaking out there's a good chance it's getting in. Wait a few hours and change it if it's still fucked.

With my daughter, we always think site first.  How long has it been on?  If you just put it on, maybe the cannula is bent.  Has it been on for 5 days, probably site has gone bad.  Did you just change the reservoir, how long has the insulin been open?  We also keep one or two unopened pens, just for emergencies.  If we think it is the insulin, get out a pen a d see what happens.  Really it is trial and error, but depending on site age and when you opened your last vial, you can make a good guess.  We have not run into her suddenly having Issues with insulin working g.  Hope that helps.

Take your hands and gently wipe them all around the adhesive on your site. If you smell insulin, in your hands, that is a leak/tunneling. Change your site.

If your site hurts a lot, change your site.

If your site feels loose, change your site.

Sites often aren’t suitable anymore well before they seem totally ready to come off. My sites can last anywhere from 2-5 days depending on where they are and what I’m doing. Usually 3-4.

Make sure you have enough infusion sets so you aren’t unnecessarily rationing infusion sets if your doctors and insurance will allow it.

With respect to your last question, site issues are easiest to diagnose. The rest is much harder. Count carbs, pay attention to if your meal was fatty or had lots of protein in it (may require more insulin), and whether you have been actively lately.

How do you treat BG with alcohol consumption?
Hi there, I figure I could look this up in the books but I figured since everyone is different, how do you guys treat your Diabetes when drinking?

I've never drank alcohol in more than a few sips, and my friend has a party in a couple weeks and wants me to drink with him. How should I care for myself before, during, and after?

comments.text:
Hi, current college student. I’m not of legal drinking age yet so I haven’t gone balls to the walls or anything, but I’ve also been trying to safely figure out how to do this. 

Definitely go into it with something substantial in your stomach. I usually go for something fatty and protein based, eggs and hash browns are my go to. Stay hydrated before/during/after. Basic drinking protocol. 

I usually try to make sure I have a CGM in and working so I can spot trouble ahead of time. The biggest problem you’ll probably have is lows, probably hours after drinking while your liver is still busy metabolizing what you’ve drank. You can either be really slack about your blousing during the night, I’ll bolus for any meals I have, but small stuff, candy, mixers, I’ll usually leave until the end of the night. I usually try to do this by including a mixed drink or cup of punch a for every few beers/shots I have. If this seems too cavalier for you, I’ve had lots of success having 15-25 carbs of a snack before bed. I try to pack it in whatever bag I take with me, usually a ziplock bag of oreos or thin mints. I’d also recommend an emergency snack just in case you do dip and have nothing on hand. 

These strategies are really important because glucagons do not work while your body is processing alcohol. When in doubt, aim high, because this isn’t the time to pass out because of a hypo. Have somebody that can recongnize your symptoms really well, this is also really tricky because being low looks and sounds and feels a lot like being drunk. Godspeed.

Some non-diabetics are susceptible to low blood sugars but this is usually following intense exercise, not as a matter of routine such as waking up

A diabetes diagnosis will usually occur after high blood sugars. You would experience intense thirst, peeing a lot, sometimes nausea, extreme weight loss, and fatigue.

Pump and injections together ?
Just wondering if it’s possible to be on the pump for background insulin but still inject for bolusing ? Can I do both or do I have to chose one ? I have been diabetic for almost twelve years and had a pump from 2010 - 2021. Thanks :)

comments.text: I’ve done somewhat the opposite of this. I’d put in an infusion set with my pump, and then disconnect  from it. Then, I’d inject long acting insulin. This way, during summers where I was really active and swimming and sweating and in the sand, I could be detached from my pump, but not have to inject every time I wanted a snack / meal because I could just reconnect my pump to bolus quickly. The long acting insulin took the place of my basal rate on my pump and I was free to only have to wear my pump when is needed to bolus.

I don’t see why not, I know people that use inhaled insulin for blousing because it acts quicker, but I’m curious why you’d want to do this? 

For me, the convenience of pumping and not having to bring pens/vials with me everywhere is one of the huge pros

I like to take shots for some meals. It works faster/better. I need more insulin on the pump for meals than I do with shots and I spike higher on the pump than I do with shots. So some meals I def use an injection!

Yes, definitely can!

Yes MINE and I am just figuring this out 3 years after dx.

What you’re experiencing likely isn’t the insulin, but the effect of a protein called AMP-activated protein kinase. As a cell keeps breaking off phosphate groups from ATP for energy, ATP turns into ADP and then AMP (tri-phosphate -> di-phosphate -> mono-phosphate), and when AMP levels rise it sends a “low energy” signal, which among other things triggers AMPK to allow glucose into the cell without needing insulin. People with type 1 who do tons of sub-zone 2 exercise can get down to frankly ridiculous insulin requirements (like 10-12u TDD), because they’re shuttling so much glucose into cells via this mechanism.

As to why, insulin resistance can have a variety of causes, and sometimes it’s a transient thing (cortisol, high levels of fatty acids in the bloodstream after a meal, etc). If you’ve already checked the main ones (weight, sleep, exercise, diet), the next step is mentioning it to your endo.

comments.text: Talk to your kids pediatrician. If they are having any symptoms, it may not be diabetes but may be just as serious.

The symptoms of high blood sugar can be numerous but just vauge enough that they can be confused with other maladies or sometimes just normal ups and downs of kids.

But in general, they present themselves in the following ways:

1. Thirst, often extreme. Kids being kids, their first intinct will often be to reach for a sugary drink to relieve the thirst, which makes it worse

2. Frequent urination (sometimes, but not always, the urine will have a mildly sweet aroma)

3. Fatigue, often extreme

4. Headaches

5. Feeling warm/sweaty without enviornmental trigger

6. Ravenous hunger, often times not helped with food.

7. Unexpected weight loss or inability to gain weight

These will often worsen or become more obvious as sugars move higher. In the most severe cases, diabetes needing immediate medical intervention will present with vomiting, shallow breathing, woozy ness, etc.

If your child has several of these symptoms regularly, then it would be wise to check with your doctor. It doesn't necessaril mean diabetes, but it could be or any other number of treatable conditions.

Failing that, most drug stores now sell over the counter gluconeters and test strips that are not absurdly expensive and do not require a prescription. You can use one of those to check your kiddo's blood sugar a few times (make sure to read up on proper testing procedure first).

If their fasting glucose (not having esten for 8 hours) is under 70 or over 120 or if their post meal glucose is over 170-180, then that is awarning sign something is up and it's time to see the doctor immediately.

But beyond that my advice would be... don't panic, regardless of what you discover via symptoms and/or testing. They may be diabetic. They may very well not. But even if they are, while it isn't fun and presents many challenges, it is treatable and manageable. And as a parent you are doing the right thing and asking the right questions by checking now.

Frio packs

She needs to be seen by an endocrinologist.  I was initially diagnosed by a family practice doc as T2 even though both my mother and my son are T1.

- monitor your sugar constantly, every 10 minutes. 
- keep plenty of juice and snacks nearby.

- if you're having a mixed drink, ask for the diet version, so a rum and Diet coke, etc. Mixed drinks with a lot of soda or soda water will be hard to manage because they'll make your sugar go way up then go crashing back down. 
- my last advice is do what makes you comfortable. if drinking feels too scary that's okay. in my experience, when you tell people you don't drink because you're diabetic they're always immediately understanding. 
- if you have a good endocrinologist or diabetes nurse ask them for advice too. like someone mentioned we're not medical experts. however as many of us know, sometimes doctors are stupid about type 1, lol. but hopefully you will have a nurse or endo you really trust one day :) 

hope that helps op. you'll be okay as long ed you're careful!

Can I reserve my pancreas?
My kid is 7 and is T1. I googled for answers to no avail. I am an organ donor, but I wondered if there’s a way to reserve my pancreas for my son to receive when I die? Just curious how I would even go about it.

We are the same blood type, btw.

comments.text: His pancreas still does some jobs. If he were to receive yours, he would trade T1d for immunosuppressants. Most people don’t find that trade off to be worth it. Usually, the people who get pancreas transplants are already getting something else transplanted, like a liver. Since they will require immunosuppressants anyway, the trade off is worth it.

Pancreas transplants are fairly rare, difficult to pull off, and generally only offer a short term benefit.  The immunosuppressants required are probably worse than controlling T1.  If I remember correctly even those with successful transplants have a 50% chance of being back on insulin at five years.  It's a lovely thought to have your kid get your pancreas but it's not really a solution.
The average lifespan of a transplanted pancreas is 10 years. The younger he is when he has a transplant, the more likely he will need more than 1.

Pancreas transplants aren't really a viable method of treating diabetes, and is considered a last resort option. Transplants don't last forever, and some don't even last a year. Even if your son got lucky he'd probably only survive a decade or two after getting a transplant. The half life of pancreas transplants is 11 years, meaning in half of patients who have them the transplant fails before 11 years, and half fail after. As far as I can tell, the record for the longest surviving pancreas transplant is 24 years. 

Type one can be managed for a lifetime, and we're closer and closer to a cure all the time. Your kid has a better chance just living with diabetes and hoping for a cure to be finished than trying to get an unnecessary transplant. I don't want to get your hopes up, but with where we are now it's pretty likely a cure will be possible by the time he is an adult.
Aside from the drawbacks noted by others, you didn't say where you live. It's a bit hard to advise when nobody knows what laws might be applicable in your jurisdiction.

It’s more than just immunosuppressive issues. His pancreas is perfectly fine. T1D isn’t a pancreas issue, it’s and antibody issue. His body is literally attacking the beta cells in the pancreas, causing the pancreas to have issues. He won’t lose the antibodies he has because there was an organ donor. People don’t really do transplants because it’s highly likely the body will eventually attack the new pancreas. There has to be some sort of antibody treatment and immunosuppressive along with the transplant. 

Most the new trials for pancreas treatment are actually trying to find a way to make the antibodies mission of killing the pancreas unsuccessful. When doing so the pancreas should go back to normal and beta cells will work again.

Immunosupressants will be needed. I am not a medical professional but your kid's immune system might think that your pancreas is also a threat so the trade off is not worth it. If they are doing fine without it, then don't let them have the misfortune of a very weak immune system that can cause more issues.

Organ transplantation is a serious surgery generally considered a last resort for people with major complications or severely brittle diabetes with complications. This is because receiving an organ through transplanting then requires the receiver to take immunoupressants for life to prevent rejection. This puts them at risk for any number of infections and other medical problems.

Transplantation also does not gaurantee their immune system won't once again attack and destory the islet cells that make insulin. In many cases, a new pancreas only "cures" someone from needing injected insulin for a short period of time.

I woukd recommend talking to your doctor about this option. It's unfortunately not the miracle cure it is sometimes believed to be, absent an emergency situation.

I will eat a snack if im below 135/7.5 before a run. You might even notice on some runs the adrenaline will increase your blood sugar. Start small and as you become comfortable, try to increase time / distance etc. It can be done - I have run a marathon & over a dozen half's. Like everything else - it's harder for us than the average person. Good luck!

I’ve never found exercise mode to be useful for cardio because the autoboluses for a rising blood sugar cause me to crash hard. I actually use sleep mode instead when exercising and it’s great because it doesn’t give the autoboluses. Regardless, I also have about 15g of sugar 15 minutes before exercising and another 15g every half hour or so if I’m doing a long run and I’ll stay pretty stable — it’ll be different for everyone but that’s what I’ve found to work for me.

I LOVE my tandem... except when it comes to exercise. If I’m doing intense cardio, I crash really hard really fast. When I first got type one, I would have to be at 250-300 in order to exercise and not crash. My old pump had a setting where you could lower your basal rate by whatever percentage before exercising. That works perfect because I would just take 50% for the hour before. That way I wouldn’t climb too high before or crash during. If it's then tanking again without him injecting more insulin, his basal insulin dose is **definitely** too high.  If he's using a CGM, then it makes it easier, but what he might want to do is fast for a day (no food or caloric drinks - best to avoid caffeine too) and see how his blood sugars move throughout the day.  If they're dropping, then he needs to reduce his basal dose.  Sadly, many endocrinologists and GPs don't try and educate patients on how to titrate their own doses and instead use the limited information on their hands to decide a dose for them - this is ineffective at best, and dangerous at worst.

As for management in general, and how to keep stabler blood sugars, in my opinion there's nothing better than low-carb/ketogenic eating.  I would highly recommend reading information such as Dr. Richard K. Bernstein's "Dr. Bernstein's Diabetes Solution: The Complete Guide to Achieving Normal Blood Sugars" as a starting point.  He's been T1D himself for many decades and is well into his 80's.  I use a heavily modified version of his low-carb routine/protocol to manage my own diabetes, and I can honestly say that it has saved my life and health.  I have stable and relatively normal blood sugars (a1c of 5.8 and dropping) and I use very little insulin to manage it, which helps to avoid large errors and swings.  It's hard to get into all the details of how to properly figure everything out, since entire essays (and indeed books) can be written on it, but yeah, that book is well worth the 10-15 bucks it costs on Amazon.  I've never felt as healthy as I do now with near-normal blood sugars.

Apologies for the long reply, but best of luck to you and your brother!  Feel free to DM me if you want more details etc.

Insulin does play a role in satiety, but it is not a main player. With that being said, insulin is actually anorexigenic, meaning it makes you feel not hungry. So it's unlikely that insulin is causing what you're experiencing.

However there is a possible link between insulin resistance and hunger. When you eat lots of high carb foods you end up craving them. It's like an itch, or an urge to keep eating them, not necessarily hunger. If you're feeling it after eating then it's probably this and not hunger. Amylin plays a role in regulating appetite. It suppresses it when you eat, so you begin to feel full and stop eating. Without amylin it is possible that you would not feel full.
The caveat here is that amylin is not the major player in satiety either. So it's unlikely to be having a very profound effect.

Hi fellow Ontarian! 👋 Sharing a bunch of info below. 

**TIPS FOR BG CONTROL**

Alright so I’m going to come from the angle of getting my A1c down to 4.9% during a recent pregnancy: 

- Document the shit out of everything while you’re waiting for your endo’s approval. If you’re on a Dexcom or Libre, I think you can enter your insulin doses or activities in the apps, but consider a separate app like MySugr or SugarMate (those two were my favourites) where you can include additional details like what you ate, illness, or what kind of activity you did. 
- Prebolus! Give that insulin at least 15 minutes before a meal unless you’re about to be physically active, then consider how active you’re going to be and adjust your timing and dose based on that. 
- Know how your body responds to different foods: pizza, fast food, and sushi tend to be difficult to give insulin for because of the delayed time for them to break down, so if you’re eating these, don’t jump in with your insulin too soon, but be prepared to need to give yourself a good dose of insulin to compensate for the tsunami of carbs. 
- If you’re finding a lot of highs/lows around exercise, take some time to research [ExCarbs](https://www.diabetesnet.com/diabetes-control/exercise-and-diabetes/excarbs-exercise/)… this page is full of crappy ads but the main content is good. The ExCarbs info is to help you figure out what level of exercise you’re doing and how much to either reduce insulin or increase carb intake by before your activity. 
- Try to find balance with your meals: protein, veg, and starch. Fibre. Try to avoid those breakfast options that spike your BG like oatmeal or Mini Wheats as it can set off your whole day.
- if you have a habit of looking at your phone while eating, make a cheeky little Lock Screen that says something like *“Sure you can eat that, but did you take your insulin for it?”*. Before I got on the CGM I had a reminder to get me to test my blood sugar that said “if you can scroll, you can test” and it helped keep me accountable to test 10-12 times a day, which brought my A1c down to about 6%. 
- If you’re interested in reading, try a copy of [The Book of Better](https://www.amazon.ca/gp/product/0307720683/) or [Bright Spots and Landmines](https://www.amazon.ca/Bright-Spots-Landmines-Diabetes-Someone/dp/0692875174/).. I found these books both to be quite helpful. 
- Celebrate your wins, and don’t beat yourself up for a bad day; they happen to everyone.  


**MOHLTC ASSISTIVE DEVICES PROGRAM**

Qualifications for insulin pump and pump supply coverage through the Assistive Devices Program is available [here](https://www.ontario.ca/page/get-support-for-diabetes-equipment-and-supplies). They’ll provide you with a pump and $2400 ($600 every 3 months) for pump supplies; anything *exceeding* that amount can be claimed on health insurances or as medical expenses for your taxes (with proof that you’ve exceeded the $2400/yr). 

Typically coverage is based on:
- You are an Ontario resident with an Ontario Health card
- You monitor your BG level at least 4 times a day (the CGM fulfills this requirement)
- You attend appointments at the recommended frequency of your endocrinologist (e.g., usually every 4-6 months)
- You have comprehension of carbohydrate counting, correction dosing, making adjustments if you’re sick, etc. 
- Number of highs/lows requiring third party intervention from family member or emergency services 
- Your HBA1c is 9% or below - note: this might not be a requirement anymore, but it still was when I was last approved 

Your clinic will complete the documentation for you; you may need to fill out the first section. You would also need to complete pump training where your diabetes educator and/or a representative from your preferred pump company would review how to use the pump (e.g., selecting an infusion site, inserting the set, filling your cartridge, setting your insulin rates such as basal rates, correction factors, insulin:carb ratio, syncing your CGM if you use one, learning about the “insulin on board” or active insulin, and reviewing other features like insulin suspension, creating new insulin setting programs, etc.) 

In my experience, an endo wants to see that you’re working toward meeting your goals because a pump isn’t a bandage solution to having good control. With that said, I’ve never heard of needing your time in range between 85-100%.
